nodes.bodyText: This can just be a lambda, can't it?
should be final.
instead of null, can we we use an AtomicReference<Predicate>? Which we get() and set()?
Sure
I'd really really prefer if we only have 1 place in this thread that we block.
Agree

I tried that way and find out it can't handle some use cases.
Eg. when the service is in INSTALLED state and starting, there is a new requestStart() call comes in and trigger a "desiredStateUpdate" event. In this case we don't want to cancel the current starting thread.
Can't we de-dupe? Like we know we're already trying to get to RUNNING, so there's nothing different that we need to do.
Probably log at debug level.
Personally I like having this at info since our state transitions are some of the most important things that happen to services.
Probably logging at warn level is more appropriate. Error should be reserved for something with negative impact. I'm not sure if that's the case here.
synchronized is not needed here.
Move this above together with other instance variables.
Not sure if this is better than the previous way. Personally I find it more difficult to read. setTimeoutAction() also takes an extra thread.

While I do like this syntax better, I'm not sure about the threads. The previous implementation relied on the scheduled thread pool, so while running it obviously uses 1 thread, but when it isn't running, that thread pool is free to do other stuff. I'm not too sure about the Timer's thread usage. I'd certainly want more info on that before accepting this change.

From Timer document: "Corresponding to each Timer object is a single background thread that is used to execute all of the timer's tasks, sequentially. "
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
I don't have a strong preference. Using Timer() makes the code look a little cleaner to me, but I'm ok with executor as well.
What does canFinish mean?

When handleCurrentStateX() is async, it need to check the next coming stateEvent to decide whether the current state handle is finished.
The check is Predicate asyncFinishActionCheck . One example is in handleStateTransitionInstalledToRunningAsync()
not needed, the default is console.
context needs to be closed in the after and the executors need to be shutdown too, otherwise you're leaking a lot of threads.
this isn't needed, you can just let this method throw.
no sleeping, just use verify(<x>, timeout(<some time>)
switch the order here, it should be expected, actual.
please no sleeping
This is the sleep in mock install() method. The test is verify that when install() times out, it's properly interrupted.
How long is the timeout though? These unit tests should be very very fast to run; at the very most 1 second each.
Timeout is parsed from config, I can set to 1 second.
these are unit tests, 10 seconds is far too long for a unit test. Each one should take a couple milliseconds.
Sure
Understand what you're doing, but why?
Also, this executor will need to be shutdown.
I moved the test from EvergreenServiceTest. This is to make sure that all reportState are processed even when lifecycle thread is in lowest priority.
Why do these need getters? If they need getters, can we keep them private or package-private?
use Getter for easier mocking. currently context is accessed in many places. I can add a TODO comment to make it private.
This seems very specific, can this be generalized more, ie apply it to all the reported-current state pairs that don't make sense.
The last reported state also needs to be reset once the reported state has been processed because after that point, it is invalid.
I feel it's unnecessary to reset this field. In this PR, all state are reported through state queue so the lastReportedState will eventually be the same as current state.
is current at this point accurate? Can't the handleX methods change what state it is in?
the PR update handleX method to not change state directly, but through internalReportState()
Yes, exactly. The current here is wrong at this point, because a new state has been reported.
"a new state has been reported." - the new state is captured in 'newState' variable , 'current' is the processed state. in this way the reported states are processed in strict order.
this needs logging now since it is called directly in the lifecycle thread.
Let's check the generation here too.
Sure. should we increment generation in every state then? Currently it's only incremented when INSTALLED

No. That can work if you're asserting that the state has not changed since you last checked, but it does not work in the case that you want the state to have changed; just not restarted the whole service.
Let's use serviceErrored since that provides a standardized way of logging errors which result in the service moving to errored.
Sure
use current or reported?
lastReported because the current state isn't updated yet
use current or last?
ditto. use lastReported because current isn't updated yet.
these lines do the same thing.
Is it ok to discard "DesiredStateUpdated"? If yes, why do we even add those to the queue?
Yes, because the "DesiredStateUpdated" just serves as a notification to notify lifecycle loop about the update. We add the events anyways to avoid race conditions
nit: update the comments

Not sure if I understand. Is asyncFinishAction used to block until the backing task inhandleXAsync actually finishes? The default value (stateEvent) -> true (in both init ln259 and reset below ln337) is only needed so that the loop exists properly for handleX sync methods?

no. 'asyncFinishAction' blocks until a new state event arrives . a stateEvent is either a new state or a 'desiredStateUpdated' notification. One example is lifecycle while loop starts the service by calling service startup() , and wait until service report RUNNING
Update comments about what stateGeneration is intended for?
Sure
Is it implicit that backingTask won't be changed again after setBackingTask, since handleX is actually executed synchronously? nit but in this case, we don't need atomic reference of backingTask?
SetBackingTask will only be called in the main lifecycle thread. I'd assume it's safe to remove atomic reference. Let me recheck
Why stopBackingTask here?
We want to stop the thread of waiting dependency ready, and process the updated state/desiredstate in next while loop
Why do we have another way to timeout different from install timeout?
Install timeout is to measure install() invocation time, but startup() timeout is to measure the time between calling startup() to reportState(RUNNING)
What are the possible current tasks?
A previous startup() invocation.
This is the only case that the async action returns false. Why is this the only case?

If the new stateEvent is a different state, then we need to go to the next loop to process the new state. If the new stateEvent is desiredStateUpdated, and the new desiredState isn't running, then the service need to stop first.
make this a long instead of Long.
Report stopping doesn't seem right. Shouldn't we request a stop here?
Inside the lifecycle thread, requestStop only sets next desiredState to FINISHED. reportStopping in here is to implement the state transition of STARTING->STOPPING.
But it isn't stopping here. If this did requestStop, then the state machine should handle the transition from STARTING->STOPPING.
Shouldn't this re-check that the dependencies are ready, since this is happening async to when we last know that the dependencies were ready?
Added
This log should be redundant, right? We already log in internalReportState.
Do we need to check if this state is RUNNING?
whether it's RUNNING or not, it should cancel the timer, go to next while loop to process the new state.

Why do we pass in INSTALLED here? The side effect seems to be removing INSTALLED from desired list if exists. Does this mean if reinstall is called during the starting->running transition, we will drop it?
I changed it to STARTING .
Add some comments about when to use lastReportedState, prevState and stateEventQueue?
Add comments?
